title: If you wrote a letter to yourself in the days just before the COVID-19 pandemic, what would you say? - Quora

response.answer_text: Dear Veronica, I know you’ve heard of coronavirus. Normally, it’s a virus that causes the common cold. You’ve gone through that hundreds of times before (the cold caused by this coronavirus), so it’s no big deal, right? Sure. But what’s about to invade the world, including your country, will be anything but “no big deal.” In fact, it’s going to be a VERY big deal. You’ll learn lots of things, both good and bad, during the next several months. First off, you’ll learn what you can deal with. I know that you’re a walker. I’ve seen you—walking fast for exercise in the parks in the evenings. It’s been fun, hasn’t it? You see dogs walking their owners, pet cute, furry felines you see walking the streets in the adjoining neighborhoods, and gaze up at the sky, feeling the nice, cold air that comes in the wintertime. I know that you also like eating out. Whether it’s been fast food (not healthy, BTW), Chinese, Italian, or seafood, you’ve enjoyed a good meal out because you like the food, the atmosphere, and the people. Yes, these are great activities, so I would tell you right now to enjoy them (and the other activities you do) while you still can, because you’re about to enter the stay-at-home period. I know you like being out and about, doing things, but you’ll need to stay in because of this virus that is 100 times worse than the coronavirus that’s made you sick for a few days. And it won’t be just you but everyone else, too. “It’s for your own good,” as someone’s mom might say. Yes—and it’s true. But I know you’ll do it. You know why? Because you’ve always been one to follow rules, and because you also care about not getting infected and possibly infecting others. That doesn’t mean you won’t go out (you’ll have to and only for necessities), but when you do, you’ll be the careful, diligent Veronica you’ve always been and put on a mask to protect yourself and others. That’s what you’ll do and will expect others to do the same. Another thing I’ve noticed about you is how idealistic you are; you expect that the people you meet will be good people (and most of them are) and act decently. That’s a great thing to be, Veronica, but you’re about to be sorely disappointed. You’ll be upset to read about people protesting and deliberately disobeying orders to put on masks and stay home because they believe it’s an “attack” on their “freedom.” Even more devastating, you’ll find out that your own leaders, at the state and federal level, will absolutely screw up their response to the coming pandemic. It was like your dad believed—people aren’t always nice or caring. He was right, to a point: people can be ignorant, corrupt, uncaring, and downright cruel. But still, you’ll see many more people who care about what’s happening and will do what they can for others, like making masks, social distancing, make adjustments in how they work, shop, and eat, and otherwise make things safer for all of us. Hey, I know that you’re a reader, so while you’re indoors, why don’t you read up more on this new disease? Read up on what it does. Read about what precautions people really need to take. Read about the nature of it. Read about the history of pandemics and how people handled them then. And read about things that aren’t related to the new disease. Reread some of your old books! Plus, if you want to really make a change, you should volunteer for virtual phone banks and call up voters to encourage them to vote. This is a presidential election year, so this is your chance to make a difference. Plus, I know you’ve done this before, so continue with your belief in being part of the solution instead of being part of the problem. Why don’t you also use the downtime you’re about to enter to just think and contemplate? Yeah, I know—you already do that. But you’re about to do even more of it. You’ll order and read a couple of books written by a wise Quoran. Because of her words, you’ll learn things about yourself and life that you never thought of before; some of it will be uplifting and reassuring and some will be uncomfortable. In the process, you’ll have time to think about who you really are and what you really want. Seriously, this will be a great time to ensconce yourself in quiet and hear your own voice rather than the voices of people who have thought they know you and therefore, tried to tell you how to live according to their standards. This time, you can listen to yourself. But still, it’s not going to be all peaches and cream. In addition to what I’ve just said about people politicizing the pandemic, you’ll have feelings about staying in, ranging from feeling safe to just wanting to get out. Hey, that’s okay, Veronica. It’s normal to feel that way, You’re only human. Look, this pandemic won’t be easy on anybody. Lots of adjustments and changes will have to be made, and mistakes will be made. And, sadly, people will die—thousands of them. It will be a very trying time, indeed. So do your part to stay safe. Protect yourself and others. Hang in there. You can’t predict what’ll happen—no one can—but you can do things now. Take it day by day, and hopefully, we’ll get through this. Take care! —Veronica from July 2020

Hey you! Just wanted to let you know that it’s okay to see the bright side. It’s okay to count it as a blessing. You’re about to go through the most insane ride of your life - and that’s kind of saying something after last year. You’ll be fine, and you’ll be able to see the small miracles and big ones too. You’re going to spend most of the spring and summer wondering if you have a brain tumor or another disease - you don’t, just so you know - and you’re going to get a diagnosis for health issues that have plagued you since you were a teenager. You’ll gain a new appreciation for your husband as you navigate a pandemic together. You’ll feel like such a team as you hunt for groceries and make meal plans and stretch resources in the early days when grocery stores are emptying. You’ll watch the Lord provide for you financially; you’ll see so many answers to prayer; you’ll find so many positives that you will have to actually fake complaining in sympathy with those who are troubled. You’ll see the good God does even through things intended for evil. You’ll become comfortable, confident, and dedicated in a classy range of masks… and you’ll feel isolated, not by staying home or wearing a mask in the library, but by the ridicule you’d get through it “if people knew you drank the liberal kool-aid”. God will give you a stack of memories a mile high, so many that you’ll fill a whole journal. You’ll stop and smell the roses, literally, as you finally get to that gardening. You’ll finally be able to manage the clutter and finish eliminating. You’ll sleep more and eat more and watch God make your body heal. And you’ll lose friends. You’ll cry when the contractor fixing your sink mentions some of the difficult outcomes of a pandemic, because someone out there understands the tension and the drama you’re going through. You’ll know over and over that you’re doing the right thing, and God controls your path and your outcome… oh, and the re-connections and friendships and bonds you’ll form will make up for the loss. You’ll see things happen that seem horrible at the time, but end up being “meant to be” and answers to prayer. So dust off your waterproof mascara, lay a towel on your husband’s shoulder for all the crying he’s going to hold you up through, and print that blessing journal you’ll create a few months in… because you’re not going to be able to write fast enough as the Lord grows you, your children, your marriage, and your home. Oh, and by the way? Don’t worry; all the things your gut tells you, science will say later. You’re not insane. Stay home, mask up, and don’t worry… you’ll be able to find hand sanitizer, and toilet paper. God is good, all the time.
